docs.lead_paragraph: THE OFTEN ELUSIVE PURSUIT OF SLEEP The causes of insomnia are numerous, ranging from medical ailments to a fear of not being able to fall asleep. EAUTY THRIVES ON adequate sleep. Good health, attractiveness and vitality depend upon looking and feeling well rested. Yet sleep problems plague more than 50 percent of adults at one time or another, experts say. Every night, more than one out of three people toss and turn in the frustrating pursuit of sleep.

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Endowment for the Humanities has announced the award of $22 million in grants for such diverse projects as the study of foreign cultures, museum renovation and an inquiry into the moral dilemmas created by scientific advances. A total of 75 grants were announced earlier this week by the endowment's chairman, William J. Bennett. They require the recipients to raise $3 for each $1 in Federal money as part of the endowment's challenge grant program. Some of the grants are relatively modest but have the effect of placing a kind of imprimatur on a program, an approval that can be pointed to in soliciting contributions from private benefactors.

docs.lead_paragraph: - dozen graduate students gathered in the seminar at New York University's Graduate School of Business was this: What was the ethical obligation of the Bechtel Corporation in 1978 when faced - simultaneously - with the Arab nations' boycott of companies doing business with Israel, and the United States law forbidding compliance with that boycott? The students started out with some rather definite answers. ''I think a company is a guest in the host country, and should follow the mores and ethics of that country,'' one woman said. ''The whole system of international relationships is based on the idea of a sovereign country.'' ''Are you arguing that Bechtel was right'' in complying with the Arab boycott, asked Robert Lindsay, who teaches the seminar, ''that it was a guest and had to follow the lead of the countries where it was doing business?''
